CatDescriptText: Mr. Charles Stuebgen, newspaper photographer, Glenshaw and Miss Connie Bell, school teacher, Lorain, Ohio, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, July 14, 1962, pg. 17  with question: "Do you think it is ethical or right for a doctor to go on 'strike' as a protest?"  Mr. Stuebgen's answer reads: "No.  Don't ask me why."  Ms. Bell's answer reads: "In the beginning, a physician takes an oath which marks him as one who is dedicated to humanity.  Violation of this oath, which is involved in such a strike, is a rejection of his profession and his purpose.  The economic standpoint is important, but the oath is supreme.  his attitude must be one of devotion, the same as that of a teacher."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Charles Stuebgen wearing striped necktie, standing in front of C.C. Mellor's, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Connie Bell wearing striped seersucker suit and sunglasses, standing in front of truck and car
